Yes, Vikings did have specific hygiene practices, although they were not as elaborate as those of some other civilizations. Here are a few examples:

- Oral hygiene: Vikings would clean their teeth using a small stick or twig with the end frayed, or with a mixture of water and herbs. They may have also used chew sticks made of birch or spruce to freshen their breath.

- Haircare: Vikings would comb their hair to keep it neat and free of tangles. They may have also used natural oils or plant extracts to condition their hair or keep it smelling fresh.

- Skincare: Vikings would often use hot stones to create steam baths or saunas, which would help to cleanse the skin and open up pores. They may have also used natural oils or plant extracts to moisturize and protect their skin.

- Bathing: While Vikings did not bathe as frequently as we do today, they did practice bathing to some degree. They may have bathed in natural bodies of water such as rivers or lakes, or used wooden tubs inside their homes for baths.

While these hygiene practices may seem simple by modern standards, they would have been effective for keeping Vikings healthy and comfortable in their day-to-day lives.
